oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Einstein and Steinmetz
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Edited photo showing Albert Einstein and Charles Steinmetz standing together. The photograph was originally taken on 23 April 1921 during a demonstration of the Radio Corporation of America's (RCA's) experimental trans-oceanic communication station at New Brunswick, NJ to a group of distinguished scientists. The photograph originially included a group of 19 scientists. The scientists were all removed except for Einstein and Steinmetz for this image. The fencing behind Einstein was recreated by a photographer. Steinmetz died in 1923, so this photograph was created after his death.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Einstein and Steinmetz with group
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Original photograph showing Albert Einstein and Charles Steinmetz standing together. The photograph was originally taken on 23 April 1921 during a demonstration of RCA's experimental trans-oceanic communication station at New Brunswick, NJ to a group of distinguished scientists. The photograph includes a group of 19 scientists. In 1924, after Steinmetz's death, a new version of the image was created in which all the scientists were all removed except for Einstein and Steinmetz.
From left to right in the photograph are: First three unidentified, David Sarnoff, Thomas J. Hayden, Dr. Ernst .J. Berg, S. Benedict, Albert Einstein, John Carson, Dr. Charles Steinmetz, Dr. A. N. Goldsmith, A. Malsin, Dr. Irving Langmuir, Dr. Albert W. Hull, E. B. Pillsbury, Dr. Saul Dushman, R.H. Ranger, Dr. G. H. Campbell, Ernst F.W. Alexanderson, and C. H. Taylor

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Barn in rear of 233 Liberty Street used by Steinmetz as private laboratory in 1900, 1901.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Charles Steinmetz lived at 233 Liberty Street in Schenectady, New York from 1897 to 1901. He used a carriage barn in the back of the house as a private home laboratory. In 1900 the barn became the original home of the General Electric Research Laboratory, which in 2008 is known as GE Global Research. In 1901 the barn the caught fire and was destroyed and the Research Laboratory moved to the GE plant in downtown Schenectady. GE published the image on 2 November 1932.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Steinmetz and Marconi
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Charles Steinmetz visits with Italian inventor Guglielmo Marconi at the General Electric plant in Schenectady, New York. Marconi shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in Physics for his contributions to wireless telegraphy, which is otherwise known as radio. Steinmetz and Marconi are on the steps of GE Building 2 in this image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Yates Boathouse
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pleasure boating was popular on the Mohawk River in the late 19th century. The center of activity was Yates Boathouse, which was located in the Stockade and owned and operated by V. Hanson Yates from 1894-1915. Yates constructed a two-story boathouse with a boat livery on the ground floor and a dance hall upstairs. Hundreds of people flocked to the Stockade to watch the annual boat races, including the 1895 regatta. Yates sold his boathouse in 1915 to the city. It was replaced by Riverside Park.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: In Maid of the Mist, Niagara
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Occasionally GE business took Steinmetz out of Schenectady. In 1895, Steinmetz rode on the "Maid of the Mist" when he went to Niagara Falls to design the high-voltage power transmission line between the Niagara Falls hydroelectric station and Buffalo. The "Maid of the Mist," in operation since 1846, is one of the country's oldest tourist attractions. Pictured, from left to right, are GE engineers Eskil Berg, Charles Steinmetz, Ernst Berg, and Langdon Gibson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Camp Mohawk- Whitney, Dempster & I on veranda
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Charles Steinmetz poses with one of his laboratory engineers, John T. H. Dempster, and Willis R. Whitney, the first head of the General Electric Research Laboratory at Steinmetz's camp on the Mohawk River. Steinmetz maintained a camp on the north side of the river in the town of Glenville. Dempster became the first employee in Whitney's new research laboratory. Steinmetz is pulling the extension cord attached to the shutter release on his camera.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Automobile, first trip of family, in yard
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Charles Steinmetz poses with his adopted family, the Haydens, and his Detroit electric automobile. Steinmetz is in the car. In front of the car, from left to right, are his grandchildren Marjorie "Midge" Hayden, William Hayden, and Joe Hayden. At the right is the children's father and Steinmetz's laboratory assistant Joseph LeRoy Hayden. The electric car is now owned by Union College and as of 2008 is on display at the Edison Exploratorium in Schenectady, NY.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nott Memorial From a Distance
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nott Memorial is a prominent feature of the Union College campus, located in Schenectady, New York. The building was formerly known as Alumni or Graduates' Hall, but was dedicated to Eliphalet Nott, Union College president from 1804-1866, in 1904. Steinmetz held various positions at Union College from 1902 to 1923, including part-time head of the Electrical Engineering Department and professor of electro-physics.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Steinmetz Cigar Box
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of inside of the Steinmetz cigar box. A typed notecard by C.V. Christensen found in the box indicates the Steinmetz cigar box was donated to the First Unitarian Society, Schenectady, NY. The box was made by Phillip Bleser in a cigar factory on Wall Street, Schenectady. Phillip C.P. Steinmetz had been smoking Blackstone cigars, but quit them because it was a non-union shop. He wrote Bleser in 1924 regarding the locating of a panatella, union made cigar. The Steinmetz cigar box was copywrited by Morganstern who sold it to P. Bleser. It was copywritten after Steinmetz' death and sold until 1946.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Bleser, Phillip; Luzon Cigar Co. Inc.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Steinmetz Cigar Box Lid
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of the top lid of the Steinmetz Cigar box. A typed notecard in the box by C.V. Christensen provides this explaination: The Steinmetz cigar box was donated to the First Unitarian Society. The box was made by Phillip Bleser in a cigar factory on Wall Street, Schenectady. C.P. Steinmetz had been smoking Blackstone cigars but quit them because it was a non-union shop. He wrote Bleser in 1924 asking if he could supply Steinmetz with a panatella, union made cigar. The Steinmetz cigar box was copywrited by Morganstern who sold it to P. Bleser. It was copywritten after Steinmetz' death and sold until 1946.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hotel Edison
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Hotel Edison, located on State Steet near the train station, was erected in 1890 and closed in the early 1930s. It was built on the site of the Givens Hotel, where Thomas Edison stayed during his first visit to Schenectady in 1886.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Arent Bradt House Before Demolition (2)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Charles Steinmetz took this photograph in December 1895 just prior to the house being torn down. The Bradt house shows the wood and brick construction typical of the Dutch dwellings in the 18th century. The building was located on the site of the current Schenectady YMCA Center.
